The second and third volume were banned and the author was sent out of Russia. He moved to Tchernovtsy where he accomplished his work and published the last two volumes.

*260  $aOdessa

*300  $a39 p.

*506  $bCensoring body: Russian state authorities
*506  $eThe first (1882) edition was not banned as the censors failed to notice the illegal character in the book. The second edition was for sale when a minister pointed out that all the books were either socialist or revolutionary. On October 29 1883, the book was banned and all the unsold copies were confiscated and destroyed.

*506  $eIn 1890 the story was banned for publlishing in the "V pamjat' Jur'eva" collection. In Dec. 1890-Feb. 1891 it was published in Part 13 of "the Works" by L.N.Tolstoj. 9700008
*041  $anor
*24500$aAlt for Norge
*260  $aPorsgrunn
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aPublication of the newspaper was upheld with great regularity 
in the Skien-Porsgrunn area, from the start of 1941. A driving force 
behind the paper was the parliament member Carl P. Wright. Several 
members of the group were arrested and sent to the Norwegian camp 
Grini. Most of them were subsequently deported either to Sachsenhausen 
or Natzweiler. The group had contacts within Parliament, amongst them 
John Larsen. Larsen was persuaded by Wright to accept a position in the 
Reichskommissariat. Larsen obliged reluctantly, as he had to enlist in 
the NS. Larsen became most valuable to the newsgroup; obtaining 
pertinent information, also smuggling envelopes and stamps from the 
Reichskommissariat, enabling the group to distribute the paper 
nationally in the Reichskommissariats envelopes. When Larsen was 
discovered, he was subjected to severe torture during interrogations, 
and subsequently died in Sachsenhausen. Carl P. Wright, arrested in 
1941, was succesfully freed by the group that published "London-nytt" 
and later transported to England. The total number of arrests is 
unknown, but at least 20 were sent to German concentration 
camps.Journalist Erling O. Pedersen died in police detention in Oslo 
due to torture. Borti Reichelt was later shot at Trandum
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aDistributed in the Skien-Porsgrunn area, as well as to contacts 
nationally. - Stencilled
*506  $eIllegal for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945
*522  $aIllegal in Norway
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal
*70000$aWright, Carl P.
^

*505  $aTwo leading members of the Norwegian Communist Party 
established the paper. All equipment was hid in a closed-down pig farm, 
and the paper kept these quarters until October 1944, when the news 
group had to go underground
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945

Norwegian news broadcastings on BBC. - Stencilled, subtitle varies

*505  $aWhen "Alt for Norge", published by the Norwegian Communist 
Party (NKP) in Bergen, shut down in the autumn of 1942, a new paper 
with the same name was published in January 1944. The number of copies 
of each issue varied; one issue was printed in 48000 copies. The paper 
continued until the end of the war

*505  $aThe first issue was published on August 9 1941, and represents 
one of the first stencilled radio-papers. More than 100 issues were 
published during the period, semi-regularly. The paper consisted mainly 
of two pages. The paper closed in March 1943 for security reasons, but 
the editor continued with other illegal work

*505  $aStrictly defined, this paper was not illegal, as the recipients

the illegal paper "Kronikken"

*2450 $aFast front (Wyller)

*260  $aStavanger
$b[s.n.]
$c1941
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing

*505  $aInitially, this was not intended as an illegal paper, but as a 
declaration. It was distributed illegally in Stavanger, Oslo and other 
parts of the country, calling upon Norwegians to resist the 
Nazi-regime. Trygve Wyller, who participated in the publishing, was 
arrested and deported to a German concentration camp, where he survived 
the war.

prison ship Westphalen. He was one of five to be saved

9700085
*041  $anor
*24500$aFri fagbevegelse
*260  $aOslo
$bThe Norwegian Federation of Trade Unions
$c1941-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aOther title: FF. - The first issue was published on January 4 
1941, then with no title. The title first appeared in no. 25, dated 
July 26 1941. The paper soon became an important contact and 
information instrument in the resistance struggle. 18000 copies were 
printed in January 1942, when the Gestapo arrested several members, 
amongst them Kaare Haugen and Per Lie. Both suffered heavy torture and 
were deported to German concentration camps. Per Lie died in the spring 
of 1945 in Dachau. Kaare Haugen survived. Oddvar Halvorsen served as 
editor until he escaped to Sweden in the autumn of 1943. In spite of 
the arrests, the paper succeeded, thanks to new volunteers. When Peder 
Soeiland was arrested, Hans G. Lund took over the work. He was killed, 
and succeeded by Thorvald Karlsen and Egil Larsen. Henry Wahlen and 
Adolf Sandbo were sent on the prisoner ship Westphalen, Wahlen died 
when the ship sank, Sandbo was one of the five survivers. Many escaped 
to Sweden. A total of 122 of the group were arrested, of these many 
were deported to German concentration camps. 19 lost their lives
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 3000-18000. - Stencilled
*506  $eIllegal for political reasons
*518  $a1941-1945
$3newspaper
*522  $aIllegal in Norway
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal

$eeditor

$epublisher

*505  $aOther title: FF. - The Bergen edition of "Fri Fagbevegelse". 
The members Olav Brunvand and Kristian Hatlevik were arrested in 1941 
and sentenced to twelve years imprisonment in Germany. The group also 
published "Radioavisen (Bergen)" in co-operation with 
"Steinorganisasjonen", and "Morgenbladet", "Tross Alt" and "Under Aaket"

9700309
*041  $anor
*24500$aNordmannen [Bergen]
*260  $aBergen
$b[s.n.]
$c1940
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aA large resistance group was established in Bergen in the 
spring of 1940, who then published "Nordmannen", financed by the exile 
government in London. The paper was well edited and had a large 
circulation. In December 1940 several of the group were arrested, 
amongst them Aaroe, Brekke, Henschien and Schnell, who recieved 
15-years sentences and were deported to Germany. One of the initiators, 
Melankton Rassmussen was executed. Two of the group continued printing 
illegal papers
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aStencilled
*506  $eIllegal for political reasons
*518  $a1940-1945
$3newspaper
*522  $aIllegal in Norway
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal
*70010$aRassmussen, Melankton
$epublisher
^

9700318
*041  $anor
*24500$aNorge
*260  $aStabekk
$bAUF
$c1941
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aPublished by the Labour Party's Youth Organisation (AUF) in 
Stabekk. The group also published "Norge krigsnytt" and "Den norske 
kvitboken". The group was disclosed in 1941, resulting in the arrest of 
40 people. 28 of these had to stand trial before a "peoples court" 
established by the German Reichkommissar, following the decree on 
prohibition of political parties
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aContent: Radio news from London. - Circulation: 1500. - 
Stencilled

9700320
*041  $anor
*24500$aNorge vaart land
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aInitially published by Arild Walder, Claes Berg and Jens 
Gruner-Hegge. Berg, Gruner-Hegge and the member Willy Vraalsen were 
arrested in June 1942, and deported to camps in Germany. They all 
returned to Norway after the war. The paper continued to publish, and 
continued later as "Verdens gang". The paper shut down in November 
1943. Arild Walder fled to Sweden
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945

9700329
*041  $anor
*24500$aNorgesposten
*260  $aBergen
$b[s.n.]
$c1940-41
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aCirculation: 3000. - Stencilled. 
*505  $aInitiated by the first members of a resistance group in Bergen; 
Lars Gjendemsjoe, Konrad Nerheim and Erling Roennestad, from the summer 
of 1940, publishing ceased in the summer of 1941. The group began 
publishing a paper in German, passing it off as a publication by a 
German resistance group. See: "Volksgenosse" and "Meldungen der 
Deutschen Soldaten in Norwegen". The group co-operated with the 
Stein-organisation, also the main distributor of the paper. In October 
1941 the Gestapo disclosed the Stein-organisation, thus also the paper. 
Ca. 200 of the arrested were deported to German concentration camps, 
where 50 died
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*506  $eIllegal for political reasons
*518  $a1940-1945
$3newspaper
*522  $aIllegal in Norway
*651  $a8040
*691  $aPolitical
*692  $aIllegal
*70010$aGjendemsjoe, Lars
$epublisher
*70010$aNerheim, Konrad
$epublisher
*70000$aRoennestad, Erling
$epublisher
*74002$aMeldungen der Deutschen Soldaten in Norwegen
$zNorgesposten
$gPublished by same organisation
*74000$aVolksgenosse
$zNorgesposten

*505  $aPublished by the Norwegian Communist Party (NKP). In May of 
1942, the Gestapo arrested several of the group and the paper ceased 
until the autumn of 1942. Brynhild Stroem and Oernulf Slaattelid were 
arrested. After severe torture, they both committed suicide in prison. 
The printer, Peter Christensen, was shot at Trandum September 5 1944. 
Several others were arrested, including the editor Alf Biem

*505  $aStarted by mr. and mrs. Aasekjaer in August of 1941, and was 
published several times weekly, often daily, until the liberation. 220 
copies of the paper exist today. The paper repeatedly changed names: 
"Sunday times", "Militaeroversikt" and "Stillingen i natt", and was 
published during the final period with no name.

*041  $anor
*2450 $aRadio-nytt
$wRadio nytt
*260  $aOslo
$bNKP
$c1941-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aThe second of the big "radio" papers published by the illegal 
Communist Party. In spite of their efforts, the Gestapo never disclosed 
the paper, thus publishing was continued until the liberation, in an 
approximate total of 300 issues. One of the editors, Lars Nordboe, was 
arrested and executed. Aksel Wold was arrested, while Walther Rygh fled 
to Sweden. Dagmar Eilerth was arrested along with her son Eindride. All 
were arrested in the autumn of 1944

*505  $aInitiated by Rolf Schultz-Haudt, the paper, published twice 
monthly, was mainly run by a group of youths consisting also of

closed when Stig was arrested on February 25 1942 along with numerous 
members of the resistance group Milorg

*505  $aA continuation of "V-posten", "Hjemmefronten" and "Aksla".

*505  $aThe paper was started by Thorolf Gregersen. One of the group, 
mr. Wathne, was arrested in October 1944, due to his engagement in

reason. The paper shut down for reason of safety for two weeks, then 
resumed. The sunday edition was called "Jernlesten"

9700385
*041  $anor
*24500$aSann roest
*260  $aHoenefoss
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-44
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aStarted by Thomas Hansen, who distributed the paper among close 
friends. Later the paper expanded, and was published once a week until 
the 10 June 1944, when the paper was hit during Gestapo's large raid of 
illegal activities in Hoenefoss. The group member Reinhardt Halvorsen 
was arrested, and shot at Trandum on September 5 1944. Hansen moved 
from Hoenefoss, and members Floritz Gundersen and Karl Larsson were 
later arrested, Larsson because of other illegal activities.

*041  $anor
*24500$aDe siste krigs-meldinger. De siste meldinger fra London. Siste

*260  $aOslo
$bLondon-nytt
$c1944-45
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aStarted in August 1944, the paper was published daily. The 
printing works and distribution were moved several times, due to near 
disclosure by the Gestapo. In January 1945, several of the distributors 
and one of the editors, Rolf Sundt, were arrested in a street razzia, 
Sundt carrying copies of the paper. He was released a month later. The 
paper continued publishing with a short pause until the liberation.
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 5000-3800. - Contents: Reports from the BBC 
morning news, articles and general news. - Stencilled

*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aBoth the Norwegian Nazi state police nad the Norwegian 
resistance movement published "fake" illegal papers in order to 
infiltrate each other. This paper was published by the group behind 
"London-nytt". Claiming to be published by an illegal group of 
deserters from the SS, it aimed at creating confusion within the Nazi 
ranks.

*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing

*505  $aThis paper, first published on October 1 1940 by three youths; 
Einar Andreassen (editor), Leif Aanestad and Per Ellingsen, was one of 
the first illegal papers in Norway. A weekly, the paper ceased 
publishing due to mass-arrests of the publishers of "Stritt folk", 
"Joessing" and "Patrioten" in October 1942. Many lost their lives in 
German concentration camps

9700401
*041  $anor
*24500$aSvart paa hvitt
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1943-44
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aWhen the group behind "Avantgarden" split up, most members 
joined in making "Svart paa hvitt", on the initiative of Hans J. Luihn. 
The group moved their printing house several times, and finally 
possessed what was probably the most advanced war time printing press. 
The paper was published weekly until the crackdown of the press in 
February 1944, when the Nazis arrested several of the members and 
seized the press. Henrik Lunde died when the prisoner ship Westphalen 
sank. Knut Esmarch was deported to a concentration camp in Germany, and 
died shortly after his release.
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of 
Norway 1940 - 1945
*505  $aCirculation: 5000. - Printed

*505  $aStarted by Hans Krag and Johan Klausen in September 1941, when 
radios were confiscated. In February 1944 several of the group were 
arrested. Klausen, Ansgar Soerlie and Johan Martinsen were sent to 
Germany on the prisoner ship Westphalen which sank. Klausen was one of 
five to survive. Continued as: "Det gryr av dag".

*505  $aStarted by Ivar Hamre and Reidar Fannemel in September 1940, 
the paper changed to "Aksla" in 1941, then in autumn of 1941 to 
"Hjemmefronten". In spring of 1942, Hamre had to flee due to his 
activities in Milorg, but the paper continued as "Rundskue".

9700433
*041  $anor
*24500$aVi
*260  $aKongsberg
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42, 1945
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aInitiated by Sven Foeyn in January of 1941, the editors were 
Olav Loekse and Dagfinn Skaar. Foeyn and Loekse were arrested during 
the Germans' raid on educators, and deported to Kirkenes. Skaar became 
the editor, and publishing continued until the autumn of 1942, when the 
group was engaged in other illegal activities. The paper resumed 
publishing in January 1942 until the liberation. One member of the 
group, Erling Winnaes, was arrested and died in Germany. Another 
member, Aage Hedenstad, was executed for his activities in the 
resistance group Milorg

9700436
*041  $anor
*24500$aVi vil oss et land (B-edition)
$balt for Norge
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1940-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aOriginally the paper was a copy of "Vi vil oss et land 
(A-edition)". Soon the publishers started to edit the material as well 
as add new material, thus creating an original paper. Most group 
members, many of them prominent press people, were engaged in other 
illegal activities. This also caused the closure of the paper. The 
Nazis shot one of the group, Arvid Hansen, also a group leader in 
Milorg, and his father. The paper was connected to "Vi vil oss et land 
(A-edition)"

9700439
*041  $anor
*24500$aVictory
$borgan for den norske presse
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1942-43
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aStarted in August of 1942, this publication of the Norwegian 
free press was published twice a week as a rule. The paper was 
discovered by the Nazi state police in July 1943. Many members of the 
group were arrested and subjected to severe interrogations. Most 
remained detained until te liberation. Some months later, a new paper 
named Victory was published
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of

9700440
*041  $anor
*24500$aVictory (V-posten)
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1943-44
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aStarted in November 1943 by a resistance group, urged to 
publish a paper with the same name as "Victory", which had been closed 
due to arrests. Initially the paper was published twice weekly, later 
three times a week. It was published as "V-posten" from February to 
June 1944, then returned to its original name. On October 16 of 1944 
and the following days, many publishers and distributors were arrested, 
and Victory was shut down

"Joessing" and "Patrioten". The publishers were arrested along with the 
publishers of the other papers. All papers were shut down

*041  $anor
*24500$aWhispering times
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aFirst issue published on September 15 1941 when the radios were 
confiscated. Published daily, as a rule. On August 7 1942, the Gestapo 
raided the paper. Many were arrested, Erik Kr. Gravdahl, Erling 
Gulbrandsen, Asbjoern Halvorsen, Ingeborg Haabeth and Asbjoern 
Halvorsen were deported to German concentration camps, but survived the 
war
*505  $aIllegal newspapers produced during the German occupation of

9700452
*041  $anor
*24500$aWhispering times
*260  $aOslo
$b[s.n.]
$c1941-42
*500  $aSource: The National Library of Norway, the W.W.II Printing 
Collection. - Author: Hans Luihn
*505  $aStarted by Mons Oppedal and Rolf Soerensen when radios were 
confiscated. The paper was published daily until Mons Oppedal was 
arrested in connection with "London-nytt" and "Norsk tidend" in July of 
1942. Rolf Soerensen went underground, and Thorvald Rogdar took over 
the paper. He was arrested in February 1944. See also "Headlines" and 
"Whispering" (Stavanger)

Sweden. - Typewritten

*505  $aPublished by Svein Molaug, Reidar Revold and Arvid Sveum. The 
group had great practical difficulties publishing the paper, and it 
eventually was closed when Sveum fled to Sweden and Molaug moved to 
Toensberg
